div.p: Greetings. I wrote to you, dearest godfather in the Lord, on the seventh of this month; at present, there is nothing to add; I did not want to neglect the opportunity to write. Although these cities, Zurich and Bern, are so close, I often wonder why there is such a rare opportunity to send letters; I wish and earnestly desire that there be more mutual commerce and goodwill between these cities.

I do not know what vexes me; it always seems to me that the hearts do not want to align properly and sufficiently in these difficult times. I groan about this to myself, but silently, and I pray to the Lord that for the sake of His word, He may reconcile the minds of these people. I have not heard anything about our Germany for a long time. I cannot forget so many churches that have both recognized and professed the truth of God's gospel for several years; I still do not cease to hope that soon we will sing a new song to the Lord.

Regarding England, since Montius left here, I have received nothing; I beg you, if you have anything, share it. I hoped that our Gervasius would be called by the people of Biel, but, as I hear, another was called, namely Funck from Constance. Everything at my home is now peaceful by the grace of God. The envoys, whom I wrote to you about in the matter of our godfather Mr. Haller, were detained beyond the appointed day; perhaps you know the reason from elsewhere: in one evening... the decision was changed.
What will happen now, I do not yet understand. May the Lord grant that we diligently seek His glory and that He does not turn His grace away from us.
Farewell very well, dearest godfather in the Lord. Greetings to your entire household above and below, young and old, all together, also to mother Klunglerin.
All of mine greet you. Greetings to all the lords and brothers and to our Gervasius. Bern, January 16, 1550.
W[olfgang] Musc[ulus], your godfather. To the most excellent theologian Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant leader of the church of Zurich, his dearest godfather in Christ. Zurich.
